Line 71: Line 71:  
It has also been apparent that the differences in cultures and the way they define what is moral and what is not depends greatly on the local environment and they way they live. And when two, or more, cultures meet there needs to be a tolerance between them or else conflict will occur until one culture’s morality is imprinted upon the others or the involved parties will grow tired of the perceived threat of each other.
 
It has also been apparent that the differences in cultures and the way they define what is moral and what is not depends greatly on the local environment and they way they live. And when two, or more, cultures meet there needs to be a tolerance between them or else conflict will occur until one culture’s morality is imprinted upon the others or the involved parties will grow tired of the perceived threat of each other.
    −
The opposite belief, imposing various degrees of standardization via a [[moral code]] and its enforcement, usually in a [[legal system]], is that such cores either can be shared or are irrelevant to the process of social control and learning proper conduct.
